awd_titl_txt: The Creeping Disaster along the Coast: Built Environment, Coastal Communities and Population Vulnerability to Sea Level Rise
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the vulnerability of humans and the built environment to the impacts of sea level rise by integrating detailed spatial housing data provided by Zillow with measures of social vulnerability, sea level rise risk, and historical flooding. This integrated dataset allows the theoretical exploration of the role of the built environment in mediating traditional human-natural system interactions within the context of slow moving, persistent or creeping disasters. Based on data from coastal communities impacted by recent hurricanes, innovative statistical techniques are used to understand the drivers of vulnerability and potential impacts of natural disasters on community resilience. The open, freely available vulnerability datasets created in this project will be foundational for future disaster preparation, planning, and post-disaster recovery. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve coastal disaster preparedness, which will save lives and economic losses in future events.

This project advances the methodological foundation of vulnerability analysis to better characterize populations and built environments  across coastal communities. These advances are driven by several data innovations. Using structure-specific characteristics derived from Zillow data, novel settlement data layers will be created at fine granularity and for different points in time to derive built-environment vulnerability indices. The settlement layers will be integrated with census population data through statistical mapping techniques to create spatially refined population distributions and ultimately compute revised measures of social vulnerability at fine granularity within sea-level rise zones. The revised social and built-up environment vulnerability layers will be combined over large areas and across several points in time to assess trends in integrated measures of vulnerability. Identifying different scenarios related to the exposure and potential impacts of sea-level rise on vulnerable places will provide insight on how coastal communities adapt to flood events and determine how particular development patterns may affect vulnerability in the future. Publications, software, and data derivatives generated during this project will be made available on the project website, GitHub and public data repositories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project has developed new intellectual and analytical frameworks for studying coastal hazards and the built environment, with direct implications for vulnerable populations and communities. Prior research on human exposure to coastal hazards primarily relied on broad assessments of populations exposed to flooding or hurricanes. However, this research had not adequately addressed two critical factors: the changing exposure of coastal communities to hazards over time and the role of the built environment in either mitigating or exacerbating localized flood risks. This gap has hindered progress in understanding the evolving risk profile of U.S. coastlines and identifying areas most vulnerable due to the existing built environment and urban development patterns. Our project has made three significant intellectual contributions to these issues, each theoretically motivated and demonstrated through data-scientific analysis. 

First, through cutting-edge research papers and the creation of the data repository Historical Settlement Data Compilation of the United States (HISDAC-US), we have provided extensive new insights into the long-term development trajectories and changing exposure profiles of all U.S. urban communities. This work, which is already being widely cited, offers large-scale assessments of the spatial development and morphology of U.S. urban areas, their evolution over time, and their impact on coastal hazards. This work has redefined our understanding of the changing long-term risk profile of the US coast. 

Second, we have enhanced understanding of the growth and transformation of at-risk coastal communities. Our project has developed new frameworks for large-scale, high-precision risk assessments, enabling detailed examination of the changing risk profiles of structures, streets, and neighborhoods. This includes studies at the national scale as well as across specific metropolitan area studies, covering topics that range from sea level rise and multi hazards exposure across the country, to structure-level flood risk in Texas, to wildfire risk in California and nationwide. These contributions will be of significant value to a wide range of stakeholders including federal, state, and local governments, scientists, insurance companies, and homeowners.

Third, we have redefined hazard risk assessments using real estate data, focusing on the age, material and financial vulnerability of buildings and neighborhoods. This includes new frameworks for evaluating the limitations and unintended effects of existing risk assessments like FEMA’s Special Flood Hazard Areas. We have also explored how fine-scale building data can assess the interaction between urban expansion and natural environments, dynamically redefining local risk profiles. These contributions are particularly noteworthy in addressing existing limitations in vulnerability indicators. Our work has laid new groundwork to enrich vulnerability assessments based on population indicators from the Decennial Census and the American Community Survey with critical information on built structure quality, condition, location, and valuation.

In summary, this project has reshaped how the scientific community studies population and built environment vulnerability to coastal hazards. We have not only advanced our understanding of natural disaster impacts on coastal communities but have also made important contributions to urban environmental planning and federal flood risk assessment. This work has also demonstrated the value of national-level property databases for identifying and understanding priorities in urban planning in the context of a range of natural hazards.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project are extensive. The project has produced a substantial set of exposure and vulnerability assessments and resources, which are now being widely utilized through the HISDAC-US data repository and GitHub Developer Platform thus contributing to open data and open science. The research received media attention in the academic and professional communities through our publications, presentations and social media posts. The project team has also grown significantly beyond three original Co-PIs. The two early career PIs have successfully transitioned into tenure-track positions, one receiving tenure and the other on course to do so. Two postdoctoral researchers have recently started academic career positions and one senior personnel took a position in industry. The project and its related products have also directly supported the graduate research of six students, with projects spanning multiple states and universities. Material produced during this project is used in courses taught at all three institutions. The initial work undertaken within the project has also led to submission and award of an NSF Analytics for Equity grant in 2023 by an early career faculty member at Arizona State University who was not part of the original research team.The research results provide an important foundation for additional future collaborative research grant submissions.
